clue: The planet Neptune is discovered by German astronomer Johann Gottfried Galle.
funFact: Neptune was the first planet found by mathematical prediction rather than empirical observation. Urbain Le Verrier calculated its position based on irregularities in Uranus's orbit.
articleContent: On September 23, 1846, acting on calculations sent by French mathematician Urbain Le Verrier, Johann Gottfried Galle pointed his telescope at the predicted spot in the sky. He found Neptune within one degree of the predicted location. It was a triumph for Newtonian physics and expanded the known solar system.

clue: President Eisenhower sends federal troops to Little Rock, Arkansas, to enforce school integration.
funFact: The soldiers escorted nine Black students, known as the 'Little Rock Nine,' into Central High School past angry mobs and the defiant Governor Orval Faubus.
articleContent: On September 24, 1957, President Eisenhower federalized the Arkansas National Guard and deployed the 101st Airborne Division to Little Rock. This executive action enforced the Supreme Court's ruling in Brown v. Board of Education. It showed that the federal government would use force to ensure the desegregation of public schools.

clue: Sandra Day O'Connor is sworn in as the first female Justice of the U.S. Supreme Court.
funFact: She was appointed by Ronald Reagan, fulfilling a campaign promise. She passed the Senate confirmation vote unanimously (99-0).
articleContent: On September 25, 1981, Sandra Day O'Connor took her seat on the highest court in the land. A moderate conservative, she became a critical swing vote in many landmark cases over her 24-year tenure. Her appointment paved the way for future female justices like Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Sonia Sotomayor.

clue: John F. Kennedy and Richard Nixon participate in the first televised presidential debate.
funFact: Radio listeners thought Nixon won, but TV viewers thought Kennedy won. Nixon looked pale and sweaty (he refused makeup), while Kennedy looked tan and confident.
articleContent: On September 26, 1960, 70 million Americans tuned in to watch the candidates debate. The event shifted the landscape of American politics, emphasizing the importance of image and charisma. Kennedy's telegenic performance is often credited with helping him win the extremely close election.

clue: Jean-François Champollion announces he has deciphered the Rosetta Stone.
funFact: Upon realizing he had cracked the code, he reportedly ran into his brother's office, shouted 'I've got it!', and promptly fainted.
articleContent: On September 27, 1822, French scholar Jean-François Champollion wrote his famous letter to the Academy of Inscriptions. He announced he had deciphered Egyptian hieroglyphs using the Rosetta Stone. He realized the script was a combination of phonetic and ideographic signs. This breakthrough unlocked thousands of years of Egyptian history.

clue: Alexander Fleming discovers penicillin in his laboratory in London.
funFact: The discovery was an accident. Fleming had left a petri dish of Staphylococcus bacteria uncovered while on vacation, and mold had grown on it, killing the bacteria.
articleTitle: The Mold That Saved the World
articleContent: On September 28, 1928, Alexander Fleming returned to his messy lab and noticed a mold (Penicillium notatum) killing bacteria in a dish. He identified the substance as penicillin. It became the world's first antibiotic, saving an estimated 200 million lives and revolutionizing medicine by making previously fatal infections treatable.

clue: The Tylenol murders begin in Chicago, leading to modern tamper-evident packaging.
funFact: Seven people died after taking Tylenol capsules laced with potassium cyanide. The killer was never caught, but the incident led to the safety seals we see on all food and medicine today.
articleContent: On September 29, 1982, a 12-year-old girl in Chicago died after taking Extra-Strength Tylenol. Six others soon died. Johnson & Johnson issued a massive recall of 31 million bottles, costing $100 million. Their transparent handling of the crisis is considered the gold standard for corporate responsibility. It resulted in federal anti-tampering laws.

clue: British Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain signs the Munich Agreement with Adolf Hitler.
funFact: Chamberlain returned to London waving the paper and declaring 'Peace for our time.' Less than a year later, WWII began.
articleContent: On September 30, 1938, leaders of Britain, France, Italy, and Germany signed the Munich Agreement, allowing Germany to annex the Sudetenland region of Czechoslovakia. It was a failed attempt to appease Hitler and avoid war. The agreement is now synonymous with the futility of negotiating with dictators.

clue: Henry Ford introduces the Model T automobile to the market.
funFact: The Model T was so successful that at one point, half of all cars in the world were Model Ts. It famously came in 'any color so long as it is black.'
articleContent: On October 1, 1908, the Ford Motor Company released the Model T. Priced at $850 (equivalent to about $25,000 today), it was the first car affordable enough for the middle class. Ford achieved this by perfecting the assembly line, which drastically reduced production time and costs, fundamentally changing American industry and society.

clue: The comic strip 'Peanuts' by Charles M. Schulz is published for the first time.
funFact: In the first strip, Charlie Brown walks by two other kids, one of whom says, 'Good ol' Charlie Brown... How I hate him!' setting the tone for the next 50 years.
articleContent: On October 2, 1950, 'Peanuts' debuted in seven newspapers. Featuring Charlie Brown, Snoopy, and the gang, it became the most popular and influential comic strip in history. At its peak, it ran in over 2,600 newspapers in 75 countries. Schulz drew every single strip himself until his retirement in 2000.

clue: O.J. Simpson is acquitted of the murders of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ron Goldman.
funFact: An estimated 150 million people tuned in to watch the verdict live. Long-distance telephone call volume dropped by 58% while the verdict was being read.
articleContent: On October 3, 1995, after a widely televised trial that lasted nearly a year, the jury found O.J. Simpson not guilty of double murder. The verdict polarized the nation along racial lines and sparked intense debates about the American criminal justice system, celebrity culture, and domestic violence.

clue: The Soviet Union launches Sputnik 1, the first artificial Earth satellite.
funFact: Sputnik was a polished metal sphere only 23 inches in diameter (about the size of a beach ball) with four external radio antennas.
articleContent: On October 4, 1957, the USSR successfully launched Sputnik 1 into low Earth orbit. The satellite did little more than transmit radio pulses (beeps) back to Earth, but its successful launch shocked the United States. It triggered the 'Sputnik crisis,' leading directly to the creation of NASA and the beginning of the Space Race.

clue: The first James Bond film, 'Dr. No', premieres in London.
funFact: Sean Connery was not the first choice for Bond. Creator Ian Fleming originally wanted Cary Grant, calling Connery an 'overgrown stuntman' (until he saw the movie and loved him).
articleContent: On October 5, 1962, Sean Connery appeared on screen as British secret agent 007. Produced on a modest budget, 'Dr. No' was a massive hit and launched one of the longest-running and most successful film franchises in history. It established the Bond formula: exotic locations, high-tech gadgets, and stylish action.

clue: The first feature-length 'talkie' film, 'The Jazz Singer', premieres in New York City.
funFact: The first spoken words in a feature film were Al Jolson ad-libbing: 'Wait a minute, wait a minute. You ain't heard nothin' yet!'
articleTitle: The End of the Silent Era
articleContent: On October 6, 1927, Warner Bros. released 'The Jazz Singer,' starring Al Jolson. While mostly a silent film with musical numbers, its synchronized dialogue sequences astonished audiences. Its success sounded the death knell for silent cinema. Within a few years, 'talkies' had completely taken over the film industry.

clue: The United States invades Afghanistan in response to the 9/11 attacks.
funFact: The operation was originally named 'Infinite Justice,' but was changed to 'Enduring Freedom' to avoid offending Muslims who believe only God can dispense infinite justice.
articleContent: On October 7, 2001, less than a month after the September 11 attacks, U.S. and British forces launched airstrikes against Taliban and Al-Qaeda targets in Afghanistan. The goal was to dismantle Al-Qaeda and remove the Taliban from power. It marked the beginning of the longest war in American history.

clue: The Great Chicago Fire begins, eventually burning for three days.
funFact: Legend blames Mrs. O'Leary's cow kicking over a lantern, but the reporter who wrote that story later admitted he made it up to make the copy more colorful.
articleContent: On the night of October 8, 1871, a fire broke out in a barn on DeKoven Street. Aided by dry weather and strong winds, the fire leaped the Chicago River and destroyed the business district. By the time it burned out, it had destroyed 17,000 buildings and left 100,000 people homeless. The city's rapid rebuilding became a legend of urban resilience.

clue: Teenage activist Malala Yousafzai is shot by the Taliban while riding a school bus.
funFact: The assassination attempt backfired spectacularly; instead of silencing her, it amplified her voice globally, leading to her becoming the youngest Nobel Peace Prize laureate in 2014.
articleContent: On October 9, 2012, a Taliban gunman boarded a bus in Pakistan and asked for Malala by name before shooting her. She was targeted for her activism promoting education for girls. She survived a critical head injury and recovered in the UK, continuing her fight for human rights and female education worldwide.

clue: The United States Naval Academy opens in Annapolis, Maryland.
funFact: The academy was founded by Secretary of the Navy George Bancroft. Before this, midshipmen were educated directly on ships, often with inconsistent results.
articleContent: On October 10, 1845, the U.S. Naval School (later renamed the Academy) opened with 50 students and seven professors. Located at old Fort Severn, its mission was to improve the then-unsatisfactory methods of instructing midshipmen. It has since become one of the most prestigious military institutions in the world.

clue: The sketch comedy show 'Saturday Night Live' premieres on NBC.
funFact: The first host was comedian George Carlin. He performed stand-up monologues but did not appear in any of the sketches.
articleContent: On October 11, 1975, 'NBC's Saturday Night' aired for the first time. Created by Lorne Michaels, the show introduced the 'Not Ready for Prime Time Players,' including Dan Aykroyd, John Belushi, and Chevy Chase. It revolutionized television comedy with its edgy, topical humor and live musical performances.

clue: Christopher Columbus makes landfall in the Americas, arriving in the Bahamas.
funFact: Columbus believed until his death that he had reached the outskirts of Asia. He named the island he landed on 'San Salvador.'
articleContent: On October 12, 1492, after a five-week voyage across the Atlantic, a lookout on the Pinta sighted land. Columbus and his crew went ashore, becoming the first Europeans since the Vikings to set foot in the Americas. This event initiated the Columbian Exchange, a massive transfer of plants, animals, culture, and disease between the Eastern and Western hemispheres.

clue: The cornerstone of the White House is laid in Washington, D.C.
funFact: George Washington selected the site but never lived in the house. John Adams was the first president to move in, in 1800.
articleContent: On October 13, 1792, construction began on the President's House. The design was by Irish-born architect James Hoban, who won a design competition. Slaves and free laborers worked together to build the sandstone structure. It was burned by the British in 1814 and subsequently rebuilt, painted white to cover the smoke damage.

clue: Chuck Yeager becomes the first person to break the sound barrier.
funFact: Yeager had broken two ribs falling off a horse two days before the flight. He had to use a broom handle to help close the cockpit hatch because he was in so much pain.
articleContent: On October 14, 1947, Captain Chuck Yeager flew the experimental Bell X-1 rocket plane, named 'Glamorous Glennis,' over the Mojave Desert. He reached a speed of Mach 1.06 (700 mph). The sonic boom he created proved that the 'sound barrier' was not a solid wall that would destroy aircraft, opening the door for supersonic flight.

clue: The sitcom 'I Love Lucy' premieres on CBS.
funFact: It was the first scripted TV show to be shot on 35mm film in front of a live studio audience. This technique allowed for high-quality reruns, effectively inventing the rerun syndication market.
articleContent: On October 15, 1951, Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz appeared on American television screens as Lucy and Ricky Ricardo. The show was an instant smash hit, topping the ratings for four of its six seasons. It set the standard for the multi-camera sitcom format that is still used today.

clue: Marie Antoinette, the former Queen of France, is beheaded by guillotine.
funFact: Her last words were 'Pardon me, sir, I did not do it on purpose,' spoken to the executioner after she accidentally stepped on his foot.
articleContent: On October 16, 1793, Marie Antoinette was convicted of treason by the Revolutionary Tribunal. Vilified by the French public for her lavish spending and Austrian heritage, she was driven through Paris in an open cart to the Place de la Révolution. Her execution symbolized the bloody end of the Ancien Régime.

clue: Gangster Al Capone is sentenced to 11 years in prison for tax evasion.
funFact: Despite being responsible for bootlegging, gambling, and multiple murders (including the St. Valentine's Day Massacre), the government could only prove he didn't pay his taxes.
articleContent: On October 17, 1931, the most notorious gangster in American history was finally brought to justice. Federal agent Eliot Ness and his 'Untouchables' had harassed Capone's operations, but it was the IRS accountants who secured the conviction. Capone was sent to Atlanta and later Alcatraz, effectively ending his reign over Chicago.

clue: The United States formally takes possession of Alaska from Russia.
funFact: The purchase price was $7.2 million, or about 2 cents per acre. Critics called it 'Seward's Folly,' believing the land was a worthless icebox.
articleContent: On October 18, 1867, the Russian flag was lowered and the U.S. flag raised at Sitka, Alaska. Secretary of State William Seward had negotiated the deal with Russia, which feared losing the territory to Britain in a future war anyway. The discovery of gold in the 1890s and oil in the 20th century turned the 'folly' into a massive economic asset.

clue: British General Lord Cornwallis surrenders at Yorktown, effectively ending the American Revolutionary War.
funFact: Cornwallis claimed he was ill and refused to attend the surrender ceremony, sending his second-in-command to offer his sword to the French instead of the Americans.
articleContent: On October 19, 1781, British forces marched out of Yorktown to surrender to the combined American and French armies. The British band reportedly played a tune called 'The World Turned Upside Down.' This defeat collapsed political support for the war in London, leading to peace negotiations and American independence.

clue: General Douglas MacArthur fulfills his promise to return to the Philippines.
funFact: The famous photo of him wading ashore was actually a re-enactment. The landing craft ran aground too far out, forcing him to walk through knee-deep water, which made for a better photo anyway.
articleContent: On October 20, 1944, American forces landed on Leyte Island. General Douglas MacArthur, who had been forced to flee the Philippines in 1942, waded onto the beach and announced in a radio broadcast, 'People of the Philippines, I have returned.' It marked the beginning of the liberation of the archipelago from Japanese occupation.

clue: Thomas Edison successfully tests the first practical incandescent light bulb.
funFact: The filament was made of carbonized cotton thread. It burned for 13.5 hours. Previous attempts had burned out in minutes.
articleContent: On October 21, 1879, at his Menlo Park laboratory, Thomas Edison solved the problem of electric lighting. While others had invented electric lights before, Edison created the first commercially practical bulb that was long-lasting and part of a complete electrical distribution system. This invention fundamentally changed human life, extending the day into the night.

clue: President JFK addresses the nation on TV, revealing the presence of Soviet missiles in Cuba.
funFact: During the speech, Kennedy announced a naval 'quarantine' of Cuba rather than a 'blockade,' as a blockade is technically an act of war.
articleContent: On October 22, 1962, President John F. Kennedy informed the American public that spy planes had discovered Soviet nuclear missile sites in Cuba, just 90 miles from Florida. He demanded their removal and announced a naval quarantine. This initiated the most dangerous 13 days of the Cold War, bringing the world to the brink of nuclear annihilation.

clue: Apple introduces the iPod, promising '1,000 songs in your pocket.'
funFact: The first iPod only worked with Mac computers and had a mechanical scroll wheel that physically turned.
articleContent: On October 23, 2001, Steve Jobs unveiled the first iPod. While MP3 players already existed, the iPod's sleek design, massive 5GB storage, and integration with iTunes made it a cultural phenomenon. It disrupted the music industry, shifting dominance from physical CDs to digital downloads and paving the way for the iPhone.

clue: The United Nations Charter enters into force, officially establishing the UN.
funFact: The term 'United Nations' was coined by Franklin D. Roosevelt during WWII to describe the Allied countries.
articleContent: On October 24, 1945, the UN was officially born after a majority of signatories, including the five permanent members of the Security Council, ratified the charter. Founded to prevent another world war, the organization replaced the ineffective League of Nations. It remains the world's primary forum for international diplomacy.

clue: The Charge of the Light Brigade takes place during the Crimean War.
funFact: The charge was a suicidal frontal assault on Russian artillery caused by a miscommunicated order. Alfred, Lord Tennyson's poem about the event was written just weeks later.
articleContent: On October 25, 1854, roughly 600 British light cavalrymen charged down a valley surrounded by Russian cannons. Due to a vague order, they attacked the wrong artillery battery. While they reached the guns, they suffered heavy casualties and were forced to retreat. It remains a legendary example of bravery and military incompetence.

clue: The Gunfight at the O.K. Corral takes place in Tombstone, Arizona.
funFact: The fight didn't actually happen in the O.K. Corral, but in a vacant lot six doors down. It lasted only 30 seconds.
articleContent: On October 26, 1881, Wyatt Earp, his brothers Virgil and Morgan, and Doc Holliday faced off against the Clanton-McLaury gang. In a flurry of gunfire, three outlaws were killed, and Virgil and Morgan were wounded. It is the most famous shootout in the history of the American Wild West.

clue: The first section of the New York City Subway opens to the public.
funFact: The fare was 5 cents. On the first day, over 150,000 people paid to ride the train, which ran from City Hall to 145th Street.
articleContent: On October 27, 1904, Mayor George McClellan Jr. used a silver lever to start the first train of the NYC Subway. He enjoyed driving it so much he refused to give up the controls until the train reached Harlem. The subway relieved the massive congestion of the city streets and allowed New York to expand rapidly into the outer boroughs.

clue: President Grover Cleveland dedicates the Statue of Liberty in New York Harbor.
funFact: The statue was a gift from France, but the pedestal was paid for by American donations, largely raised by a newspaper campaign led by Joseph Pulitzer.
articleContent: On October 28, 1886, thousands of spectators watched the dedication of 'Liberty Enlightening the World.' Designed by Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi with an internal framework by Gustave Eiffel, the copper statue was the tallest structure in New York at the time. It became a beacon of hope for millions of immigrants arriving at Ellis Island.

clue: The U.S. stock market crashes on 'Black Tuesday,' signaling the start of the Great Depression.
funFact: Investors lost $14 billion in a single day. Rumors circulated that traders were jumping out of windows on Wall Street, though these were largely exaggerated.
articleContent: On October 29, 1929, the roaring twenties came to a screeching halt. Panic selling on the New York Stock Exchange caused stock prices to collapse completely. The crash wiped out thousands of investors and destroyed confidence in the economy. It triggered a global economic downturn that would last until World War II.

clue: Orson Welles broadcasts a radio adaptation of 'The War of the Worlds,' causing panic.
funFact: The broadcast was presented as a series of breaking news bulletins interrupting a musical program, which confused listeners who tuned in late and thought Martians were actually invading New Jersey.
articleContent: On October 30, 1938, 23-year-old Orson Welles and his Mercury Theatre on the Air performed H.G. Wells's sci-fi novel. The realistic news-bulletin format convinced many listeners that an alien invasion was underway. While the extent of the 'mass panic' has been debated by historians, the broadcast demonstrated the immense power of mass media.

clue: Martin Luther posts his 95 Theses on the door of the Castle Church in Wittenberg.
funFact: Luther didn't intend to split the church; he just wanted to debate the sale of indulgences (paying money for forgiveness of sins).
articleContent: On October 31, 1517, German monk Martin Luther pinned a list of arguments against Church corruption to the church door. Thanks to the printing press, his ideas spread rapidly across Europe. This act sparked the Protestant Reformation, a religious and political upheaval that permanently divided Christianity and reshaped the map of Europe.

clue: Michelangelo's ceiling frescoes in the Sistine Chapel are exhibited to the public for the first time.
funFact: Michelangelo hated the job. He considered himself a sculptor, not a painter, and wrote a poem about how painting the ceiling gave him a goiter and made his belly hang under his chin.
articleContent: On November 1, 1512, the doors of the Sistine Chapel in the Vatican were thrown open to reveal Michelangelo's masterpiece. Commissioned by Pope Julius II, the work took four years to complete. The central panels depict scenes from the Book of Genesis, including the iconic 'Creation of Adam.' It remains one of the most famous works of art in human history.

clue: Howard Hughes flies the 'Spruce Goose,' the largest flying boat ever built.
funFact: The plane flew only once, for about 26 seconds, covering one mile at an altitude of 70 feet. Despite its nickname, it was made almost entirely of birch, not spruce.
articleContent: On November 2, 1947, billionaire Howard Hughes piloted the H-4 Hercules (mockingly called the Spruce Goose) on its maiden and only flight. Built to transport troops during WWII, it wasn't completed until after the war ended. With a wingspan of 320 feet, it held the record for the largest wingspan of any aircraft until 2019.

clue: The Soviet Union launches Sputnik 2, carrying the first living creature into orbit, a dog named Laika.
funFact: Laika was a stray dog found on the streets of Moscow. Scientists believed that a stray would be accustomed to extreme cold and hunger.
articleContent: On November 3, 1957, Laika became the first animal to orbit the Earth. Tragically, the technology to de-orbit the spacecraft had not yet been developed, so it was a one-way mission. Laika died a few hours into the flight from overheating, though for years the Soviet government claimed she survived for a week. Her mission proved that living organisms could survive microgravity.

clue: British archaeologist Howard Carter discovers the entrance to King Tutankhamun's tomb in Egypt.
funFact: The entrance was found by a water boy who was digging a hole for a water jar in the sand. He hit the top step of the staircase leading down to the tomb.
articleContent: On November 4, 1922, after years of fruitless searching in the Valley of the Kings, Howard Carter unearthed a staircase leading to the tomb of the boy king Tutankhamun. Unlike other pharaonic tombs that had been looted in antiquity, this one was nearly intact, filled with thousands of priceless artifacts, including the famous golden death mask.

clue: Guy Fawkes is arrested beneath the House of Lords, foiling the Gunpowder Plot.
funFact: Fawkes was found guarding 36 barrels of gunpowder. Today, his mask is a symbol of anonymity and protest, popularized by the movie 'V for Vendetta.'
articleContent: On November 5, 1605, a group of English Catholics attempted to blow up the House of Lords during the State Opening of Parliament to kill King James I. The plot was betrayed by an anonymous letter. Guy Fawkes was caught in the cellar with the explosives. The failure of the plot is celebrated annually in Britain as Guy Fawkes Night (Bonfire Night).

clue: Abraham Lincoln is elected as the 16th President of the United States.
funFact: Lincoln won with only 40% of the popular vote because the opposition was split among three other candidates. He didn't carry a single Southern state.
articleContent: On November 6, 1860, Abraham Lincoln became the first Republican to win the presidency. His victory on an anti-slavery expansion platform was the final straw for the Southern states. By the time of his inauguration in March 1861, seven states had seceded from the Union, setting the stage for the American Civil War.

clue: The Bolsheviks seize power in Petrograd, launching the Russian Revolution.
funFact: It is called the 'October Revolution' because Russia was still using the Julian calendar, which was 13 days behind the Gregorian calendar used by the West.
articleContent: On November 7, 1917 (October 25 Old Style), Vladimir Lenin and the Bolshevik Party led an armed insurrection against the Provisional Government in Petrograd (now St. Petersburg). They stormed the Winter Palace with relatively little bloodshed. This event established the world's first communist state and eventually led to the formation of the Soviet Union.

clue: Wilhelm Röntgen discovers X-rays while experimenting with cathode rays.
funFact: He called them 'X-rays' because 'X' stands for the unknown in mathematics. The first X-ray image he took was of his wife's hand; seeing her bones, she exclaimed, 'I have seen my death!'
articleContent: On November 8, 1895, German physicist Wilhelm Röntgen noticed a fluorescent glow in his lab coming from a screen near a cathode ray tube, even though the tube was covered in cardboard. He realized a new type of ray was passing through solid objects. His discovery revolutionized medicine, earning him the first Nobel Prize in Physics in 1901.

clue: The Berlin Wall falls, symbolizing the end of the Cold War.
funFact: The wall fell by accident. East German official Günter Schabowski mistakenly announced that travel restrictions were lifted 'immediately,' causing thousands to rush the gates.
articleContent: On November 9, 1989, the barrier that had divided East and West Berlin for 28 years was breached. Following a confused press conference, border guards, overwhelmed by crowds and lacking orders, opened the gates. East and West Berliners climbed onto the wall, celebrating and chipping away pieces. It paved the way for German reunification the following year.

clue: The United States Marine Corps is founded at Tun Tavern in Philadelphia.
funFact: The first Marines were recruited in a bar. The proprietor, Robert Mullan, was appointed the principal recruiting officer.
articleContent: On November 10, 1775, the Continental Congress passed a resolution to raise two battalions of Marines for service during the Revolutionary War. They were originally intended as naval infantry to fight aboard ships and conduct amphibious landings. Today, the Marine Corps Birthday is celebrated annually with a traditional cake-cutting ceremony.

clue: An armistice is signed, ending the fighting of World War I at the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month.
funFact: The last soldier to die in WWI was an American, Henry Gunther, who was killed at 10:59 AM, one minute before the ceasefire.
articleContent: On November 11, 1918, in a railway carriage in the Forest of Compiègne, France, the Allies and Germany signed an armistice. The guns fell silent on the Western Front, ending four years of trench warfare that claimed millions of lives. The date is now commemorated as Veterans Day in the U.S. and Remembrance Day in the Commonwealth.

clue: Ellis Island closes after processing over 12 million immigrants since 1892.
funFact: At its peak, Ellis Island processed over 11,000 immigrants per day. Doctors used a 'six-second physical' to check for obvious ailments as people walked up the stairs.
articleContent: On November 12, 1954, the immigration inspection station at Ellis Island in New York Harbor permanently closed. For 62 years, it served as the primary entry point for European immigrants to the United States. Today, it is a national museum, and it is estimated that 40% of all current U.S. citizens can trace at least one ancestor to Ellis Island.

clue: The Vietnam Veterans Memorial is dedicated in Washington, D.C.
funFact: The design by 21-year-old student Maya Lin was initially controversial. Critics called it a 'black gash of shame,' but it became one of the most beloved and emotional monuments in the country.
articleContent: On November 13, 1982, thousands of veterans marched to the dedication of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial. The monument consists of two black granite walls inscribed with the names of the 58,000 service members who died or went missing in the war. Its reflective surface allows visitors to see themselves while reading the names of the fallen.

clue: Journalist Nellie Bly departs New York to travel around the world in less than 80 days.
funFact: She completed the journey in 72 days, beating the fictional record of Phileas Fogg from Jules Verne's novel.
articleContent: On November 14, 1889, investigative journalist Nellie Bly boarded a steamship to attempt a circumnavigation of the globe. Sponsored by Joseph Pulitzer's 'New York World,' her trip became a media sensation. She traveled by ship, train, and rickshaw, meeting Jules Verne himself in France along the way. Her success proved the capability of modern travel.

clue: Intel releases the 4004, the world's first commercially available microprocessor.
funFact: The chip had as much computing power as the first electronic computer (ENIAC), which filled an entire room, yet the 4004 was the size of a fingernail.
articleContent: On November 15, 1971, Intel advertised the 4004 in 'Electronic News.' Designed by Federico Faggin, Ted Hoff, and Stan Mazor, this 4-bit CPU started the digital revolution. Before this, computers were built using custom circuits. The microprocessor allowed for the creation of personal computers and the smart devices we use today.

clue: Francisco Pizarro captures Incan Emperor Atahualpa at the Battle of Cajamarca.
funFact: Despite being outnumbered 168 to 80,000, the Spanish won because they had guns, horses, and steel armor, none of which the Incas had ever seen.
articleContent: On November 16, 1532, Spanish conquistador Francisco Pizarro invited the Inca Emperor Atahualpa to a feast in the grand plaza of Cajamarca. It was a trap. The Spanish ambushed the unarmed Incan attendants, slaughtering thousands and capturing the Emperor. Atahualpa later offered a room full of gold for his ransom, which Pizarro accepted before executing him anyway.

clue: The Suez Canal opens in Egypt, linking the Mediterranean and Red Seas.
funFact: The composer Giuseppe Verdi was commissioned to write the opera 'Aida' for the canal's opening, but it wasn't finished in time.
articleContent: On November 17, 1869, the Suez Canal was officially inaugurated. Built under the direction of Ferdinand de Lesseps, the 120-mile artificial waterway drastically reduced the travel time between Europe and Asia by eliminating the need to sail around Africa. It remains one of the world's most vital shipping lanes.

clue: Mickey Mouse makes his public debut in the animated short 'Steamboat Willie'.
funFact: It wasn't the first Mickey cartoon produced, but it was the first to find a distributor because it featured synchronized sound, a novelty at the time.
articleContent: On November 18, 1928, 'Steamboat Willie' premiered at the Colony Theater in New York. Walt Disney provided all the voices himself. The cartoon's success saved the Disney studio from bankruptcy and launched a media empire. The image of Mickey whistling at the ship's wheel remains the logo of Walt Disney Animation Studios.

clue: Abraham Lincoln delivers the Gettysburg Address.
funFact: Lincoln was not the main speaker. Edward Everett spoke for two hours before him. Lincoln's speech lasted only two minutes.
articleTitle: Four Score and Seven Years Ago
articleContent: On November 19, 1863, at the dedication of the Soldiers' National Cemetery in Gettysburg, Pennsylvania, President Lincoln delivered a 272-word speech. Though he thought the speech was a failure at the time, it redefined the Civil War as a struggle not just for the Union, but for 'a new birth of freedom' and human equality.

clue: The Nuremberg Trials begin to prosecute Nazi war criminals.
funFact: The defendants were provided with German-English interpreters and headphones, pioneering the system of simultaneous translation used in the UN today.
articleContent: On November 20, 1945, the International Military Tribunal convened in Nuremberg, Germany. Twenty-four high-ranking Nazis, including Hermann Göring, were tried for crimes against peace, war crimes, and crimes against humanity. The trials established the legal precedent that individuals can be held responsible for their actions even when following orders from a government.

clue: The first manned hot air balloon flight takes place in Paris.
funFact: The first passengers on a balloon (sent up months earlier) were a sheep, a duck, and a rooster to test if the air at high altitude was breathable.
articleContent: On November 21, 1783, Jean-François Pilâtre de Rozier and François Laurent d'Arlandes flew a balloon designed by the Montgolfier brothers over Paris. They traveled 5.5 miles in 25 minutes. This event marked the first time humans successfully defied gravity in a sustained, untethered flight.

clue: President John F. Kennedy is assassinated in Dallas, Texas.
funFact: Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson was sworn in as President on Air Force One just two hours later, with Jackie Kennedy standing beside him still wearing her bloodstained pink suit.
articleContent: On November 22, 1963, President John F. Kennedy was shot while riding in a presidential motorcade through Dealey Plaza. The governor of Texas was also wounded. The assassination shocked the world and led to numerous conspiracy theories, though the Warren Commission concluded that Lee Harvey Oswald acted alone.

clue: The first episode of the sci-fi series 'Doctor Who' airs on the BBC.
funFact: The premiere was overshadowed by the JFK assassination, which had happened the day before, so the BBC repeated the episode the following week to ensure people saw it.
articleContent: On November 23, 1963, British viewers were introduced to a mysterious time traveler known only as 'The Doctor' and his time machine, the TARDIS (which looked like a police box). Originally intended as an educational show for children, it evolved into a global cult phenomenon and the longest-running science fiction TV show in the world.

clue: Charles Darwin publishes 'On the Origin of Species'.
funFact: Darwin sat on his theory for 20 years, afraid of the backlash. He finally published it because another naturalist, Alfred Russel Wallace, was about to publish the same idea.
articleContent: On November 24, 1859, Charles Darwin published his groundbreaking work. The book introduced the scientific theory that populations evolve over the course of generations through a process of natural selection. It challenged the dominant religious views of the time and became the foundation of modern evolutionary biology.

clue: Albert Einstein presents his field equations for General Relativity to the Prussian Academy of Sciences.
funFact: General Relativity predicts that massive objects warp the fabric of space-time, which is what we perceive as gravity. It replaced Newton's law of universal gravitation.
articleContent: On November 25, 1915, Albert Einstein completed his decade-long search for a new theory of gravity. His equations showed that matter tells space-time how to curve, and space-time tells matter how to move. The theory was confirmed in 1919 during a solar eclipse, making Einstein a worldwide celebrity.

clue: The film 'Casablanca' premieres in New York City.
funFact: The line 'Play it again, Sam' is never actually spoken in the movie. Ilsa says, 'Play it, Sam. Play As Time Goes By.'
articleContent: On November 26, 1942, 'Casablanca' premiered at the Hollywood Theater. Starring Humphrey Bogart and Ingrid Bergman, it was rushed to release to capitalize on the Allied invasion of North Africa. Though expected to be just another war movie, it became one of the most beloved films in history, winning the Oscar for Best Picture.

clue: Alfred Nobel signs his last will and testament, establishing the Nobel Prizes.
funFact: Nobel invented dynamite. He created the peace prize because a newspaper mistakenly published his obituary calling him the 'Merchant of Death,' and he wanted to leave a better legacy.
articleContent: On November 27, 1895, Swedish chemist Alfred Nobel signed his will at the Swedish-Norwegian Club in Paris. He left 94% of his massive fortune to establish five prizes in Physics, Chemistry, Physiology or Medicine, Literature, and Peace. The prizes are awarded annually to those who have conferred the 'greatest benefit to humankind.'

clue: Ferdinand Magellan's expedition passes through the strait that now bears his name and enters the Pacific Ocean.
funFact: Magellan named the new ocean 'Pacific' (peaceful) because the waters were so calm compared to the stormy Atlantic he had just left.
articleContent: On November 28, 1520, three ships commanded by Ferdinand Magellan navigated the treacherous 370-mile passage at the tip of South America. They emerged into a vast ocean. Magellan underestimated the size of the Pacific, thinking he would reach the Spice Islands in days. It took nearly four months, during which many crew died of scurvy.

clue: Atari releases 'Pong', the first commercially successful video game.
funFact: The prototype was installed in a tavern in California. It broke down a few days later because the coin box was jammed with too many quarters.
articleContent: On November 29, 1972, Atari announced the release of Pong. It was a simple 2D tennis sports game. Its success proved that the video game industry could be viable. It launched the arcade craze of the 1970s and eventually led to the home console market.

clue: Michael Jackson releases 'Thriller', which becomes the best-selling album of all time.
funFact: Seven of the album's nine tracks were released as singles, and all of them reached the top 10 on the Billboard Hot 100.
articleContent: On November 30, 1982, 'Thriller' hit the shelves. Produced by Quincy Jones, it blended pop, rock, funk, and R&B. Fueled by the popularity of the 'Billie Jean' and 'Beat It' music videos (and later the 'Thriller' short film), the album spent 37 weeks at number one. It broke racial barriers on MTV and remains a cultural touchstone.

clue: Rosa Parks refuses to give up her seat on a bus in Montgomery, Alabama.
funFact: Rosa Parks was not just a tired seamstress; she was the secretary of the local NAACP chapter and had attended activist training weeks before the incident.
articleTitle: The Mother of the Freedom Movement
articleContent: On December 1, 1955, Rosa Parks was arrested for refusing to surrender her seat to a white passenger on a segregated bus. Her arrest sparked the Montgomery Bus Boycott, a 381-day protest led by a young Martin Luther King Jr. The boycott ended when the Supreme Court ruled that bus segregation was unconstitutional.

clue: Napoleon Bonaparte crowns himself Emperor of the French at Notre Dame Cathedral.
funFact: During the ceremony, Napoleon broke protocol by taking the crown from the Pope's hands and placing it on his own head, symbolizing that he owed his title to no one but himself.
articleContent: On December 2, 1804, Napoleon Bonaparte solidified his power by becoming the first Frenchman to hold the title of Emperor in a thousand years. The lavish ceremony was designed to legitimize his regime. By crowning himself, he demonstrated that his authority came from his own merit and the will of the people, not divine right granted by the Church.

clue: The world's first SMS text message is sent.
funFact: The message was sent from a computer to a cellphone because phones didn't have keyboards yet. The message simply read: 'Merry Christmas.'
articleContent: On December 3, 1992, engineer Neil Papworth sent the first Short Message Service (SMS) text to the director of Vodafone, Richard Jarvis. It would take years for the technology to catch on, but eventually, texting became the most widely used data application in the world, changing how humans communicate forever.

clue: The American ship Mary Celeste is found drifting in the Atlantic, completely abandoned.
funFact: The ship was in seaworthy condition with plenty of food and water, and the cargo was untouched. The fate of the crew remains one of the greatest maritime mysteries of all time.
articleContent: On December 4, 1872, the British brig Dei Gratia spotted the Mary Celeste drifting erratically. A boarding party found the ship deserted. The lifeboat was missing, but personal belongings were left behind. Theories about what happened range from mutiny and piracy to sea monsters and insurance fraud, but no definitive answer has ever been found.

clue: The 21st Amendment is ratified, repealing Prohibition in the United States.
funFact: Upon signing the amendment, President Franklin D. Roosevelt reportedly said, 'I think this would be a good time for a beer.'
articleContent: On December 5, 1933, Utah became the 36th state to ratify the 21st Amendment, officially ending the 13-year ban on the manufacture and sale of alcohol. Prohibition had failed to stop drinking and instead fueled organized crime. It remains the only constitutional amendment passed specifically to repeal a previous one.

clue: Two ships collide in Halifax Harbor, causing the largest man-made explosion prior to the atomic bomb.
funFact: The blast was so powerful it temporarily emptied the harbor of water and shattered windows 50 miles away.
articleContent: On December 6, 1917, the French cargo ship SS Mont-Blanc, loaded with wartime explosives, collided with the Norwegian vessel SS Imo. The resulting fire ignited the cargo, leveling the Richmond district of Halifax, Nova Scotia. Approximately 2,000 people were killed and 9,000 injured in the blinding flash and shockwave.

clue: Japanese forces attack the U.S. naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii.
funFact: The attack happened on a Sunday morning because the Japanese believed Americans would be relaxed and less alert. The radar station actually detected the incoming planes, but they were mistaken for a scheduled flight of B-17s.
articleTitle: A Date Which Will Live in Infamy
articleContent: On December 7, 1941, the Imperial Japanese Navy launched a surprise military strike against the U.S. Pacific Fleet. The attack killed 2,403 Americans and destroyed or damaged 19 navy ships. The following day, President Franklin D. Roosevelt asked Congress to declare war, officially bringing the United States into World War II.

clue: Musician John Lennon is shot and killed outside his apartment in New York City.
funFact: Earlier that day, Lennon had autographed a copy of his album 'Double Fantasy' for his killer, Mark David Chapman.
articleContent: On December 8, 1980, John Lennon was returning to The Dakota apartment building with his wife Yoko Ono when he was shot four times. His death triggered a global outpouring of grief. Lennon was not just a music icon but a symbol of the peace movement. Crowds gathered at the building for days, singing 'Imagine' and 'Give Peace a Chance.'

clue: The animated special 'A Charlie Brown Christmas' premieres on CBS.
funFact: CBS executives hated the special before it aired. They thought it was too slow, too religious, and hated that it used real children's voices instead of adults.
articleContent: On December 9, 1965, Charlie Brown searched for the true meaning of Christmas. Despite the network's doubts, the special was a massive critical and commercial success. It won an Emmy and popularized the aluminum Christmas tree (by mocking it). It has aired every year since, becoming a holiday staple.

clue: The first Nobel Prizes are awarded in Stockholm, Sweden.
funFact: The Peace Prize is the only one not awarded in Stockholm; it is presented in Oslo, Norway, per Alfred Nobel's will.
articleContent: On December 10, 1901, the fifth anniversary of Alfred Nobel's death, the first Nobel Prizes were handed out. Recipients included Wilhelm Röntgen (Physics) for discovering X-rays and Henri Dunant (Peace) for founding the Red Cross. The prizes instantly became the most prestigious awards in the intellectual world.

clue: King Edward VIII abdicates the British throne to marry American divorcee Wallis Simpson.
funFact: He is the only British monarch to voluntarily resign the crown. His reign lasted only 326 days, one of the shortest in history.
articleTitle: The King Who Gave Up the Crown
articleContent: On December 11, 1936, King Edward VIII made a radio broadcast announcing his decision to abdicate. The Church of England and the government refused to let him marry a twice-divorced woman while King. He chose love over duty, famously stating, 'I have found it impossible to carry the heavy burden of responsibility... without the help and support of the woman I love.'

clue: Guglielmo Marconi receives the first transatlantic radio signal.
funFact: The signal was the letter 'S' (three dots) in Morse code. Critics initially claimed he was hallucinating or hearing static, but the technology was quickly verified.
articleContent: On December 12, 1901, in St. John's, Newfoundland, Marconi heard a signal transmitted from Cornwall, England, over 2,000 miles away. Physicists had argued that radio waves traveled in straight lines and would not follow the curvature of the Earth. Marconi proved them wrong (thanks to the ionosphere), paving the way for global radio communication.

clue: Saddam Hussein is captured by U.S. forces found hiding in a 'spider hole' in Iraq.
funFact: He had $750,000 in US currency, two AK-47s, and a pistol with him, but he surrendered without a fight.
articleContent: On December 13, 2003, American soldiers discovered the deposed Iraqi dictator hiding in a small underground bunker near his hometown of Tikrit. The capture of Saddam Hussein was a high point for the U.S. occupation, though the insurgency continued to grow. He was later tried by an Iraqi court and executed in 2006.

clue: Norwegian explorer Roald Amundsen becomes the first person to reach the South Pole.
funFact: Amundsen beat his British rival, Robert Falcon Scott, by 34 days. He used sled dogs, which proved superior to Scott's ponies and motor sleds.
articleTitle: Race to the Bottom of the World
articleContent: On December 14, 1911, Amundsen and his team planted the Norwegian flag at the geographic South Pole. Their meticulous planning and use of Inuit survival techniques allowed them to return safely. Scott's team arrived a month later, demoralized to find Amundsen's tent, and tragically died on the return journey.

clue: The Bill of Rights is ratified, becoming the first ten amendments to the U.S. Constitution.
funFact: There were originally 12 proposed amendments. One of the two that failed (regarding congressional salaries) was eventually ratified 202 years later as the 27th Amendment.
articleContent: On December 15, 1791, Virginia became the final state necessary to ratify the Bill of Rights. These amendments guaranteed essential freedoms such as speech, religion, and the press, and protected citizens from government overreach. They were added to appease Anti-Federalists who feared the Constitution gave the central government too much power.

clue: Colonists dump 342 chests of tea into Boston Harbor to protest British taxes.
funFact: The protestors dressed as Mohawk warriors to disguise their identities. The tea destroyed would be worth nearly $2 million today.
articleContent: On December 16, 1773, the Sons of Liberty staged a political protest at Griffin's Wharf in Boston. 'Taxation without representation' had reached a breaking point. The destruction of the tea infuriated the British government, which responded with the Coercive Acts, escalating the tension that would lead to the American Revolution.

clue: The Wright brothers achieve the first powered, heavier-than-air flight.
funFact: The first flight lasted only 12 seconds and covered 120 feet—shorter than the wingspan of a modern Boeing 747.
articleContent: On December 17, 1903, near Kitty Hawk, North Carolina, Orville and Wilbur Wright made history. After years of testing gliders, they successfully flew their 'Flyer' under its own power. It was a cold, windy morning, and only five people witnessed the birth of modern aviation.

clue: The 13th Amendment is officially proclaimed, abolishing slavery in the United States.
funFact: Mississippi did not officially ratify the amendment until 1995, and due to a paperwork error, didn't notify the National Archives until 2013.
articleContent: On December 18, 1865, Secretary of State William Seward proclaimed the adoption of the 13th Amendment. Unlike the Emancipation Proclamation, which was a wartime measure, the amendment permanently outlawed slavery and involuntary servitude in the entire nation, completing the primary objective of the Civil War.

clue: Apollo 17 returns to Earth, marking the end of the manned moon landings.
funFact: Eugene Cernan, the last man to walk on the moon, wrote his daughter's initials, 'TDC', in the lunar dust. Because there is no wind, they are likely still there today.
articleContent: On December 19, 1972, the command module of Apollo 17 splashed down in the Pacific Ocean. It marked the conclusion of NASA's Apollo program. No human has traveled beyond low Earth orbit since. The mission broke several records, including the longest moonwalk and largest lunar sample return.

clue: The United States formally takes possession of the Louisiana Territory from France.
funFact: The purchase doubled the size of the United States overnight at a cost of roughly 4 cents per acre.
articleContent: On December 20, 1803, the French flag was lowered and the U.S. flag raised in New Orleans. Napoleon had sold the massive territory to fund his wars in Europe. The acquisition secured American control of the Mississippi River and opened the vast western frontier for expansion.

clue: Walt Disney's 'Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs' premieres, the first full-length cel-animated feature.
funFact: Critics called the project 'Disney's Folly' during production, predicting it would bankrupt the studio. Instead, it became the highest-grossing sound film of all time until 'Gone with the Wind.'
articleContent: On December 21, 1937, the audience at the Carthay Circle Theatre gave 'Snow White' a standing ovation. Before this, animation was seen as filler for short subjects. Disney proved that cartoons could sustain a feature-length narrative and elicit deep emotions, launching the Golden Age of Animation.

clue: The Brandenburg Gate in Berlin reopens after nearly 30 years.
funFact: West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl walked through the gate to meet East German Prime Minister Hans Modrow, symbolizing the end of the division of Germany.
articleContent: On December 22, 1989, amidst heavy rain and cheering crowds, the Brandenburg Gate was officially reopened. It had been trapped in the 'death strip' of the Berlin Wall since 1961. The reopening was the emotional climax of the peaceful revolution that brought down the Iron Curtain in East Germany.

clue: The first successful human kidney transplant is performed in Boston.
funFact: The donor and recipient were identical twins, Ronald and Richard Herrick. Because they were genetically identical, there were no issues with organ rejection.
articleContent: On December 23, 1954, Dr. Joseph Murray led a team at Brigham Hospital to perform a revolutionary surgery. By transplanting a kidney between identical twins, they bypassed the immune system's rejection response. The success opened the door to modern organ transplantation, eventually earning Murray a Nobel Prize.

clue: Apollo 8 astronauts become the first humans to orbit the Moon and broadcast a Christmas Eve message.
funFact: During the broadcast, the crew took turns reading from the Book of Genesis. They also captured the famous 'Earthrise' photo, showing the Earth rising above the lunar horizon.
articleContent: On December 24, 1968, Frank Borman, Jim Lovell, and William Anders entered lunar orbit. In a live television broadcast watched by one billion people, they showed the cratered surface of the moon. They ended the broadcast with, 'Good night, good luck, a Merry Christmas, and God bless all of you - all of you on the good Earth.'

clue: George Washington leads the Continental Army across the icy Delaware River.
funFact: The crossing was done at night during a severe winter storm. The password for the operation was 'Victory or Death.'
articleContent: On the night of December 25, 1776, George Washington launched a desperate surprise attack. His army, demoralized and shrinking, crossed the frozen Delaware River to attack Hessian mercenaries in Trenton, New Jersey. The victory the next morning saved the American Revolution from collapse and boosted morale across the colonies.

clue: A massive 9.1 magnitude earthquake triggers a tsunami in the Indian Ocean.
funFact: The earthquake released energy equivalent to 23,000 Hiroshima bombs. It was the third-largest earthquake ever recorded.
articleContent: On December 26, 2004, a megathrust earthquake struck off the coast of Sumatra, Indonesia. It generated massive tsunami waves up to 100 feet high that devastated coastlines in 14 countries. Over 230,000 people lost their lives in one of the deadliest natural disasters in recorded history.

clue: Charles Darwin sets sail on the HMS Beagle.
funFact: Darwin was only 22 years old and was hired as a companion to the captain, not the ship's naturalist. He suffered terrible seasickness for most of the five-year voyage.
articleContent: On December 27, 1831, the HMS Beagle departed Plymouth, England, on a survey mission to South America. The observations Darwin made during this voyage, particularly on the Galapagos Islands, formed the basis for his theory of evolution by natural selection, which he would publish decades later.

clue: The Lumière brothers hold the first commercial public screening of a motion picture.
funFact: Legend says that when they showed a film of a train arriving at a station, the audience ran to the back of the room in terror, thinking the train would hit them.
articleContent: On December 28, 1895, in the basement of the Grand Café in Paris, Auguste and Louis Lumière projected ten short films to a paying audience. This event is widely considered the birth of cinema. The device they used, the Cinématographe, could record, develop, and project motion pictures.

clue: The U.S. Army kills over 200 Lakota people at Wounded Knee Creek.
funFact: The massacre effectively ended the Indian Wars in North America. Twenty U.S. soldiers were awarded the Medal of Honor for the action, a decision that remains controversial today.
articleContent: On December 29, 1890, the U.S. 7th Cavalry attempted to disarm a camp of Lakota Sioux. A shot was fired (it is unclear by whom), and the soldiers opened fire with Hotchkiss guns. The massacre resulted in the deaths of men, women, and children. It stands as a tragic symbol of the mistreatment of Native Americans.

clue: The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) is officially formed.
funFact: At its height, the USSR covered 22.4 million square kilometers, making it the largest country in the world, spanning 11 time zones.
articleContent: On December 30, 1922, a treaty was signed unifying Russia, Ukraine, Belarus, and the Transcaucasian Republics into the USSR. This created the world's first communist state, which would become a global superpower and the primary rival of the United States during the Cold War until its collapse in 1991.

clue: Queen Elizabeth I grants a Royal Charter to the British East India Company.
funFact: The company eventually became so powerful that it had its own private army of 260,000 men—twice the size of the British Army—and effectively ruled India for a century.
articleContent: On December 31, 1600, the Governor and Company of Merchants of London Trading into the East Indies was incorporated. Originally formed to trade in spices, it grew into a massive monopoly that dominated global trade in cotton, silk, tea, and opium. It played a central role in the expansion of the British Empire.
